notes: Das Wort 'Здравей' leitet sich vom bulgarischen Wort 'здрав' (gesund) ab und ist wie ein Wunsch nach Gesundheit.
notes_bg_to_de: Wörtlich ein Gesundheitsgruß; informell und ganztägig nutzbar. Näher als 'Добър ден'.
notes_de_to_bg: Für Deutschsprachige: 'Здравей' (zdravej) ≈ 'Hallo'; von 'здрав' (gesund). 'Здрасти' = sehr informell.
etymology: From Proto-Slavic 'zdravъ' (healthy) - literally a wish for good health
cultural_note: Standard informal greeting used throughout the day in Bulgaria. More casual than 'Добър ден'
linguistic_note: Stress on first syllable: ЗДРА-вей. Can be shortened to 'Здрасти' in very informal contexts

notes_bg_to_de: Morgengruß bis ca. 10–11 Uhr; formeller als 'Здравей'.
notes_de_to_bg: Entspricht 'Guten Morgen'; in Bulgarien endet er oft früher (~10 Uhr).
etymology: Compound: 'добро' (good) + 'утро' (morning). Common Slavic greeting pattern
cultural_note: Formal morning greeting used until approximately 10-11 AM in Bulgaria
linguistic_note: Stress on 'до́бро у́тро'. Both words stressed separately

examples.translation: Guten Morgen! Wie haben Sie geschlafen?

notes_bg_to_de: Formeller Tagesgruß ab spätem Morgen bis frühen Abend.
notes_de_to_bg: Wie 'Guten Tag'; festes Maskulinum 'добър' im Ausdruck, keine Flexion.
etymology: Compound: 'добър' (good, from Proto-Slavic *dobrъ) + 'ден' (day, from Proto-Slavic *dьnь)
cultural_note: Most common formal daytime greeting in Bulgaria, used from late morning until evening. More neutral than time-specific greetings
linguistic_note: Masculine adjective 'добър' remains unchanged in this fixed expression. Stress: до́бър де́н

notes_bg_to_de: Höflicher Abendgruß; formeller als ein einfaches 'Здрасти'.
notes_de_to_bg: Wie 'Guten Abend'; eher bei Erstkontakt/Höflichkeit verwendet.
etymology: Compound: 'добър' (good) + 'вечер' (evening, from Proto-Slavic *večerъ)
cultural_note: Evening greeting used after approximately 6 PM in Bulgaria. Considered more formal than casual greetings
linguistic_note: Fixed masculine form. Evening greetings in Bulgaria mark a clear cultural transition from day to evening

notes_bg_to_de: Verabschiedung zur Nacht; wörtlich 'leichte/angenehme Nacht'.
notes_de_to_bg: Wie 'Gute Nacht'; beim Auseinandergehen, nicht als Abendgruß.
etymology: Compound: 'лека' (light/easy, from леко) + 'нощ' (night, from Proto-Slavic *noktь)
cultural_note: Said when parting for the night, not as an evening greeting. Literally wishes someone an easy/light night
linguistic_note: Feminine adjective 'лека' agrees with feminine noun 'нощ'. Stress: ле́ка но́щ

notes_bg_to_de: Formelles Abschiedswort: 'bis zum Wiedersehen'.
notes_de_to_bg: Direkt 'Auf Wiedersehen'; Alternativen: 'Чао' (informell), 'До скоро' (bis bald).
etymology: Compound: 'до' (until) + 'виждане' (seeing, from root вид- 'to see'). Literally 'until seeing' = 'until we see each other'
cultural_note: Standard formal goodbye in Bulgaria. For informal settings, 'Чао' (Italian loanword) is more common
linguistic_note: Verbal noun form. Alternative informal: 'До скоро' (see you soon). Stress: довиждане

notes_bg_to_de: Vielseitig: Bitte (Anfrage), Bitte schön (Antwort), 'Hier bitte' (Reichen).
notes_de_to_bg: 'Моля' deckt mehrere deutsche Höflichkeitsformen ab (bitte/gern geschehen/hier bitte).
etymology: From verb 'моля се' (to pray, beg). Related to Old Church Slavonic 'молити'
cultural_note: Multifunctional: 'please' (request), 'you're welcome' (response), 'here you go' (offering). Essential politeness marker in Bulgarian
linguistic_note: First person singular form used as standalone interjection. Can be intensified: 'много моля' (please very much)

notes_bg_to_de: Standarddank; verstärkbar mit 'много' (sehr).
notes_de_to_bg: Entspricht 'Danke'; 'мерси' ist geliehen (frz.) und informeller.
etymology: Compound: 'благо' (blessing, good) + 'даря' (to give). Literally 'I give thanks/blessing'
cultural_note: Standard thank you. Can be intensified with 'много' (много благодаря). Alternative: 'мерси' (French loanword, informal)
linguistic_note: First person singular present tense of 'благодаря'. Stress: благодаря́. More formal than 'мерси'

notes_bg_to_de: Höfliche Entschuldigung oder Anrede (Aufmerksamkeit erbitten).
notes_de_to_bg: Entspricht 'Entschuldigung'; als Anrede z. B. 'Извинете, ...'.
etymology: Imperative of 'извинявам' (to excuse). Root: вина (fault, guilt)
cultural_note: Used both for apology and to get attention politely (like 'excuse me'). Important for Bulgarian social etiquette
linguistic_note: Formal/plural imperative form. Informal singular: 'извини'. Stress: извине́те

notes_bg_to_de: Persönliches Bedauern; stärker als höfliches 'Извинете'.
notes_de_to_bg: Wie 'Es tut mir leid'; für echte Entschuldigung, nicht nur 'Entschuldigen Sie'.
etymology: From root жал- (grief, pity). Related to 'жалко' (pitiable, regrettable)
cultural_note: Expresses genuine regret or sympathy. Stronger and more personal than 'извинете'. Used when truly apologizing
linguistic_note: First person singular present. Distinguishes regret (съжалявам) from politeness (извинете)

etymology: From Proto-Slavic *čelověkъ. Related to Old Church Slavonic члов  ѣкъ
cultural_note: Basic word for 'person/human'. Also used impersonally like German 'man' or English 'one'
linguistic_note: Irregular plural: 'хора' (people). Gender: masculine. Stress: чо́век
notes_de_to_bg: Für Deutschsprachige: 'Човек' ≈ 'Mensch'. Betonung: чо́век. Maskulinum. Sehr häufig verwendet.
notes_bg_to_de: За българите: 'Човек' на немски е 'Mensch'. Съществително име на немски. Много често използвана дума.

etymology: From 'семе' (seed) + suffix -ейство. Related to Latin 'semen'. Literally 'those from the same seed'
cultural_note: Family is central in Bulgarian culture. Extended family gatherings are common and important
linguistic_note: Neuter noun. Collective meaning. Stress: семе́йство
notes_de_to_bg: Für Deutschsprachige: 'Семейство' ≈ 'Familie'; von 'семе (Samen)'. Betonung: семе́йство. Neutrum. Sehr häufig verwendet.
notes_bg_to_de: За българите: 'Семейство' на немски е 'Familie'. Съществително име на немски. Много често използвана дума.

etymology: From Latin 'casa' (house) via Romanian. Replaced older Slavic 'дом' in Bulgarian
cultural_note: Traditional Bulgarian houses often have gardens. Home ownership culturally important
linguistic_note: Feminine noun. Stress: къ́ща. Distinct from 'дом' (home, as concept)
notes_de_to_bg: Für Deutschsprachige: 'Къща' ≈ 'Haus'. Betonung: къ́ща. Femininum. Sehr häufig verwendet.
notes_bg_to_de: За българите: 'Къща' на немски е 'Haus'. Съществително име на немски. Много често използвана дума.

etymology: From verb 'уча' (to learn/teach) + suffix -лище (place of). Place of learning
cultural_note: Education highly valued in Bulgaria. School year starts September 15th
linguistic_note: Neuter noun. Stress: учи́лище. Related: учител (teacher)
notes_de_to_bg: Für Deutschsprachige: 'Училище' ≈ 'Schule'; von 'уча (lernen)'. Betonung: учи́лище. Neutrum. Sehr häufig verwendet.
notes_bg_to_de: За българите: 'Училище' на немски е 'Schule'. Съществително име на немски. Много често използвана дума.

etymology: From Proto-Slavic *orbota (hard work, labor). Related to 'раб' (slave, worker)
cultural_note: Work-life balance gradually changing. Traditional strong work ethic in Bulgarian culture
linguistic_note: Feminine noun. Also used as verb 'работя' (to work). Stress: рабо́та
notes_de_to_bg: Für Deutschsprachige: 'Работа' ≈ 'Arbeit'. Betonung: рабо́та. Femininum. Sehr häufig verwendet.
notes_bg_to_de: За българите: 'Работа' на немски е 'Arbeit'. Съществително име на немски. Много често използвана дума.

etymology: From Proto-Slavic *gordъ (fortified settlement, castle). Related to Russian 'город'
cultural_note: Bulgaria has many historic cities. Sofia (София) is the capital
linguistic_note: Masculine noun. Also means 'castle' in archaic usage. Stress: гра́д
notes_de_to_bg: Für Deutschsprachige: 'Град' ≈ 'Stadt'. Betonung: гра́д. Maskulinum. Sehr häufig verwendet.
notes_bg_to_de: За българите: 'Град' на немски е 'Stadt'. Съществително име на немски. Много често използвана дума.

notes: 'Село' bedeutet Dorf und ist mit anderen slawischen Wörtern für Siedlung verwandt.
etymology: Bulgarian noun from Slavic root. Definite article is postfixed in Bulgarian
cultural_note: Common everyday word in Bulgarian. Useful for A1 learners
linguistic_note: Bulgarian noun. Gender: Check ending (-ъ/-й usually masculine, -а/-я feminine, -е/-о neuter). Definite article suffix: -ът/-та/-то
notes_de_to_bg: Für Deutschsprachige: 'Село' ≈ 'Dorf'. Neutrum. Sehr häufig verwendet.
notes_bg_to_de: За българите: 'Село' на немски е 'Dorf'. Съществително име на немски. Много често използвана дума.

notes: 'Книга' stammt aus dem Altslawischen und war ursprünglich eine Bezeichnung für eine Schriftrolle oder ein gebundenes Werk.
etymology: Bulgarian noun from Slavic root. Definite article is postfixed in Bulgarian
cultural_note: Common everyday word in Bulgarian. Useful for A1 learners
linguistic_note: Bulgarian noun. Gender: Check ending (-ъ/-й usually masculine, -а/-я feminine, -е/-о neuter). Definite article suffix: -ът/-та/-то

notes_bg_to_de: За българите: 'Книга' на немски е 'Buch'. Съществително име на немски. Много често използвана дума.

etymology: From Proto-Slavic *xorna (food, nourishment). Related to verb 'храня' (to feed)
cultural_note: Bulgarian cuisine features shopska salad, banitsa, kebapche. Food central to hospitality
linguistic_note: Feminine noun. Related: 'хранене' (nutrition), 'хранителен' (nutritional). Stress: храна́
notes_de_to_bg: Für Deutschsprachige: 'Храна' ≈ 'Essen'. Betonung: храна́. Femininum. Sehr häufig verwendet.
notes_bg_to_de: За българите: 'Храна' на немски е 'Essen'. Съществително име на немски. Много често използвана дума.

notes: 'Вода' ist Wasser und hat denselben indoeuropäischen Ursprung wie das deutsche 'Wasser'.
etymology: From Proto-Slavic *voda. Cognate with English 'water', German 'Wasser' (all from PIE *wódr̥)
cultural_note: Mineral water (минерална вода) very popular in Bulgaria. Many natural springs
linguistic_note: Feminine noun. Plural: 'води' (waters, can mean bodies of water). Stress: вода́
notes_de_to_bg: Für Deutschsprachige: 'Вода' ≈ 'Wasser'. Betonung: вода́. Femininum. Sehr häufig verwendet.
notes_bg_to_de: За българите: 'Вода' на немски е 'Wasser'. Съществително име на немски. Много често използвана дума.

notes: Das bulgarische Wort 'заедно' (zaedno) bedeutet 'zusammen' und ist aus der Präposition 'за' (für, zu) und der Zahl 'едно' (eins) gebildet – wörtlich ‚für eins‘ bzw. ‚auf ein gemeinsames Ziel‘. Es spiegelt die kulturelle Betonung von Einheit, gemeinschaftlichem Handeln und geteiltem Zweck wider.
etymology: Compound of 'за' (for, towards) + 'едно' (one) — literally 'for one'/'towards one [goal]'.
cultural_note: Reflects a cultural emphasis on unity, collective action, and shared purpose.
linguistic_note: Adverb; häufig mit 'с' (mit) verwendet: 'заедно с [jemandem]' = 'zusammen mit ...'.
notes_de_to_bg: Für Deutschsprachige: 'заедно' ≈ 'zusammen'. Unveränderliches Adverb. Häufig verwendet.
notes_bg_to_de: За българите: 'заедно' на немски е 'zusammen'. Наречие. Често използвана.
